message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing urinary retention after vaginal delivery, and the most appropriate immediate treatment is urethral catheterization to drain the bladder. Antimuscarinic drugs and pelvic floor muscle strengthening may be used as long-term management, while pessary insertion is used for prolapse of pelvic organs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum urinary retention, and urethral catheterization is the most appropriate treatment to address this issue. Antimuscarinic drugs are used to treat overactive bladder, which is not the case here. Pelvic floor muscle strengthening and pessary insertion may be helpful in preventing urinary incontinence in the future, but they are not appropriate for treating postpartum urinary retention.

The patient is experiencing urinary retention so the most appropriate treatment is urethral catheterization to relieve the pressure and prevent further complications. Antimuscarinic drugs are used for overactive bladder, pelvic floor muscle strengthening is used for stress urinary incontinence, and pessary insertion is used for prolapse, none of which are appropriate for this patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum urinary retention, which can be caused by the use of anesthesia and pelvic trauma. The most appropriate treatment is urethral catheterization, which can help the patient void and relieve abdominal pressure. Antimuscarinic drugs are used to treat overactive bladder, while pelvic floor muscle strengthening and pessary insertion are used for urinary incontinence or pelvic organ prolapse, which are not the primary issues in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing urinary retention, which can be an immediate complication of vaginal delivery. Urethral catheterization is the most appropriate treatment to relieve the obstruction and allow for bladder emptying. Antimuscarinic drugs and pelvic floor muscle strengthening are not indicated for acute urinary retention. Pessary insertion may be helpful for stress urinary incontinence but not for acute urinary retention.

Antimuscarinic drugs are used for overactive bladder, and pelvic floor muscle strengthening and pessary insertion are used for pelvic organ prolapse, which are not the primary concerns in this case.
